Authors:
Wanyi Zhao, Wen-Bo Liao, Li-Bing Zhang, Kewang Xu, Xin-Mao
Zhou, Qianyi Yin, Liang Zhang, Ngan Thi Lu, Ralf Knapp, Qiang Fan
Title:
A global plastid phylogeny uncovers extensive cryptic
speciation in the fern genus Hymenasplenium (Aspleniaceae)
Keywords:
Asplenium; cryptic species; eupolypods II; fern phylogeny;
pantropical distribution
Abstract:
The fern genus Hymenasplenium (Aspleniaceae) is one of the
two genera in the family. It is generally recognized among modern
pteridologists. However, its infrageneric relationships and species
diversity have been unclear and controversial. The molecular studies so
far have had small taxon and character sampling. In the present study,
DNA sequences of six plastid markers of 158 accessions representing ca.
40 (ca. 80% of species diversity) out of ca. 50 (including 16
undetermined) known species of Hymenasplenium, and 16 species of
Asplenium were used to infer a phylogeny with maximum likelihood,
Bayesian inference, and maximum parsimony approaches. Our major results
include: (1) the currently defined Hymenasplenium is strongly supported
as monophyletic; (2) three major clades representing early splits in
Hymenasplenium are identified, with the Old World species being strongly
supported as monophyletic; (3) extensive cryptic speciation in the Old
World is discovered demonstrating the complexity of evolution of the
genus; and (4) six strongly or moderately supported subclades in the Old
World clade are revealed, differing from one another in molecular,
morphological, and geographical features.
